Key Match Events: Darius Garland led Cleveland with 40 points and nine assists.
Chris Boucher came off the bench and made all his four attempts, including 3-for-3 from beyond the arc, to help Toronto take a 33-27 lead after the first quarter.
Boucher finished with 23 points and 12 rebounds.
Barnes had 24 points, 10 rebounds and eight assists Thursday.
Mobley recorded 21 points, 11 rebounds and six assists.
Pre-Game Insights: Before facing the Cleveland Cavaliers, Raptors head coach Darko Rajakovic said how important it is for struggling teams like his to play against the best teams. It’s a chance to see how you measure up.
Post-Match Reflections: Rajakovic said, 'We did not get the win tonight but I’m really proud of how our guys cheered for each other, how they competed, how they gave it all they had tonight,' while lamenting the free-throw disparity and offensive rebounding.

Rajakovic reflected, 'We did a good job of moving the ball, creating closeouts, attacking them again and creating opportunities. A lot of guys contributed tonight but, in the end, the difference was also in rebounding.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Cavaliers (33-4) came into Thursday’s game boasting the best record in the entire league, and are now riding a 16-game win streak that includes an impressive victory over best-in-West Oklahoma City on Wednesday.

One of the underlying storylines whenever these two teams meet is how the two former lottery picks fare against each other. The Cavaliers selected Evan Mobley third in the 2021 draft, while the Raptors picked Scottie Barnes fourth. Barnes would go on to win the rookie of the year award.

In 11 head-to-head games, there hasn’t been a lot to choose between the two: Mobley has averaged 16.1 points, 10.3 rebounds and 2.5 assists; Barnes has averaged 15.7 points, 7.1 rebounds and 5.5 assists.
Others: Cavaliers all-star Donovan Mitchell sat out the game for rest and Caris LeVert started in his place. He finished the game with 18 points.

The Raptors’ Ochai Agbaji missed his first game of the season following a left hip bruise suffered Wednesday in New York. He had been the only player on the Raptors roster to appear in every game this season.

Toronto was also without rookies Jonathan Mogbo and Jamison Battle, who are on assignment with the 905 along with newly minted 10-day contract signee Eugene Omuruyi. Bruce Brown was a late scratch with left knee injury management.
